premises:
Not false or false is true. People in this club who perform in school talent shows often attend and are very engaged with school events.
People in this club either perform in school talent shows often or are inactive and disinterested community members.
People in this club who chaperone high school dances are not students who attend the school.
All people in this club who are inactive and disinterested members of their community chaperone high school dances.
All young children and teenagers in this club who wish to further their academic careers and educational opportunities are students who attend the school. 
Bonnie is in this club and she either both attends and is very engaged with school events and is a student who attends the school or is not someone who both attends and is very engaged with school events and is not a student who attends the school.
conclusion: Bonnie performs in school talent shows often.
true_response:
<lean>
-- Entities and predicates
axiom Person : Type
axiom Bonnie : Person

axiom InClub : Person → Prop
axiom PerformOften : Person → Prop
axiom AttendEngaged : Person → Prop
axiom InactiveDisinterested : Person → Prop
axiom ChaperoneDances : Person → Prop
axiom StudentAttendsSchool : Person → Prop
axiom YoungOrTeen : Person → Prop
axiom WishFurtherAcademic : Person → Prop

-- Premises
axiom taut : (¬ False) ∨ False
-- People in this club who perform often attend and are very engaged with school events.
axiom ax2 : ∀ x : Person, InClub x ∧ PerformOften x → AttendEngaged x
-- People in this club either perform often or are inactive and disinterested.
axiom ax3 : ∀ x : Person, InClub x → (PerformOften x ∨ InactiveDisinterested x)
-- People in this club who chaperone dances are not students at the school.
axiom ax4 : ∀ x : Person, InClub x ∧ ChaperoneDances x → ¬ StudentAttendsSchool x
-- All inactive and disinterested club members chaperone dances.
axiom ax5 : ∀ x : Person, InClub x ∧ InactiveDisinterested x → ChaperoneDances x
-- All young/teen club members who wish to further academics are students (likely irrelevant here).
axiom ax6 : ∀ x : Person, InClub x ∧ YoungOrTeen x ∧ WishFurtherAcademic x → StudentAttendsSchool x
-- Bonnie is in the club and either (attends+engaged and is a student) or (not attends+engaged and not a student).
axiom ax7 : InClub Bonnie ∧ ((AttendEngaged Bonnie ∧ StudentAttendsSchool Bonnie) ∨ (¬ AttendEngaged Bonnie ∧ ¬ StudentAttendsSchool Bonnie))

-- Goal: Bonnie performs in school talent shows often.
theorem goal : PerformOften Bonnie := by
  have hClub : InClub Bonnie := (And.left ax7)
  have hOr : (AttendEngaged Bonnie ∧ StudentAttendsSchool Bonnie) ∨ (¬ AttendEngaged Bonnie ∧ ¬ StudentAttendsSchool Bonnie) := (And.right ax7)
  -- Split on the Bonnie-specific disjunction.
  cases hOr with
  | inl hAS =>
      -- Case 1: AttendEngaged and Student
      have hA : AttendEngaged Bonnie := And.left hAS
      have hS : StudentAttendsSchool Bonnie := And.right hAS
      have hPI : PerformOften Bonnie ∨ InactiveDisinterested Bonnie := ax3 Bonnie hClub
      cases hPI with
      | inl hP => exact hP
      | inr hI =>
          -- Inactive leads to chaperone and hence not student, contradicting hS.
          have hCh : ChaperoneDances Bonnie := ax5 Bonnie ⟨hClub, hI⟩
          have hNotS : ¬ StudentAttendsSchool Bonnie := ax4 Bonnie ⟨hClub, hCh⟩
          exact False.elim (hNotS hS)
  | inr hNotAS =>
      -- Case 2: ¬AttendEngaged and ¬Student
      have hNotA : ¬ AttendEngaged Bonnie := And.left hNotAS
      have _hNotS : ¬ StudentAttendsSchool Bonnie := And.right hNotAS
      -- From ax2, Club ∧ Perform → AttendEngaged, so with Club and ¬AttendEngaged we get ¬Perform.
      have hNotP : ¬ PerformOften Bonnie := by
        intro hP
        have hA : AttendEngaged Bonnie := ax2 Bonnie ⟨hClub, hP⟩
        exact hNotA hA
      -- From Club → (Perform ∨ Inactive) and ¬Perform, deduce Inactive.
      have hPI : PerformOften Bonnie ∨ InactiveDisinterested Bonnie := ax3 Bonnie hClub
      have _hI : InactiveDisinterested Bonnie := Or.resolve_left hPI hNotP
      -- This branch does not yield PerformOften; proof cannot be completed.
      sorry
</lean>

PROOF STATUS: FAILED

  | inl hAS =>

  | inr hNotAS =>
      -- Case 2: ¬AttendEngaged and ¬Student
      have hNotA : ¬ AttendEngaged Bonnie := And.left hNotAS
      have _hNotS : ¬ StudentAttendsSchool Bonnie := And.right hNotAS
      -- From ax2, Club ∧ Perform → AttendEngaged, so with Club and ¬AttendEngaged we get ¬Perform.
      have hNotP : ¬ PerformOften Bonnie := by
        intro hP
        have hA : AttendEngaged Bonnie := ax2 Bonnie ⟨hClub, hP⟩
        exact hNotA hA
      -- From Club → (Perform ∨ Inactive) and ¬Perform, deduce Inactive.
      have hPI : PerformOften Bonnie ∨ InactiveDisinterested Bonnie := ax3 Bonnie hClub

      sorry

false_response:
<lean>
-- Entities
axiom Person : Type
axiom Bonnie : Person

-- Predicates
axiom InClub : Person → Prop
axiom PerformsOften : Person → Prop
axiom AttendsEngaged : Person → Prop
axiom InactiveDisinterested : Person → Prop
axiom ChaperonesDances : Person → Prop
axiom StudentAtSchool : Person → Prop
axiom YoungOrTeen : Person → Prop
axiom WishesFurtherAcademic : Person → Prop

-- Premises
-- 1) "Not false or false is true." (a tautology)
axiom premise1 : True

-- 2) Club members who perform in school talent shows often attend and are very engaged with school events.
axiom premise2 : ∀ x : Person, InClub x ∧ PerformsOften x → AttendsEngaged x

-- 3) Club members either perform in school talent shows often or are inactive and disinterested community members.
axiom premise3 : ∀ x : Person, InClub x → (PerformsOften x ∨ InactiveDisinterested x)

-- 4) Club members who chaperone high school dances are not students who attend the school.
axiom premise4 : ∀ x : Person, InClub x ∧ ChaperonesDances x → ¬StudentAtSchool x

-- 5) All club members who are inactive and disinterested chaperone high school dances.
axiom premise5 : ∀ x : Person, InClub x ∧ InactiveDisinterested x → ChaperonesDances x

-- 6) All young children and teenagers in this club who wish to further their academic careers are students who attend the school.
axiom premise6 : ∀ x : Person, InClub x ∧ YoungOrTeen x ∧ WishesFurtherAcademic x → StudentAtSchool x

-- 7) Bonnie is in the club, and either (she attends and is very engaged with school events and is a student)
--    or (she is not someone who both attends and is very engaged with school events and is not a student).
axiom premise7a : InClub Bonnie
axiom premise7b : (AttendsEngaged Bonnie ∧ StudentAtSchool Bonnie) ∨ ¬(AttendsEngaged Bonnie ∧ ¬StudentAtSchool Bonnie)

open Classical

-- Goal: Prove the negation of the conclusion "Bonnie performs in school talent shows often."
theorem neg_conclusion : ¬PerformsOften Bonnie := by
  -- Attempted proof (unsuccessful)
  -- We assume Bonnie performs often and try to derive a contradiction.
  intro hPerf
  have hAttend : AttendsEngaged Bonnie := by
    have : InClub Bonnie := premise7a
    exact premise2 Bonnie ⟨this, hPerf⟩
  -- From premise7b and hAttend, in either case we can derive StudentAtSchool Bonnie classically:
  have hStudent : StudentAtSchool Bonnie := by
    cases premise7b with
    | inl h =>
      exact h.right
    | inr h =>
      have hnnS : ¬¬StudentAtSchool Bonnie := by
        intro hNotS
        exact h ⟨hAttend, hNotS⟩
      exact byContradiction hnnS
  -- From InClub and Student, we can show she cannot chaperone (or else contradict premise4):
  have hNoChap : ¬ChaperonesDances Bonnie := by
    intro hChap
    have hNotStudent : ¬StudentAtSchool Bonnie := premise4 Bonnie ⟨premise7a, hChap⟩
    exact hNotStudent hStudent
  -- From premise3, Bonnie is either performing often or inactive; if inactive then she chaperones (premise5), contradicting hNoChap.
  -- However, this only eliminates the 'inactive' branch and does not yield a contradiction from the assumption hPerf itself.
  -- Therefore, the negation ¬PerformsOften Bonnie does not follow from the given premises via this route.
  sorry
</lean>

PROOF STATUS: FAILED
false_lean_code:

  -- We assume Bonnie performs often and try to derive a contradiction.
  intro hPerf
  have hAttend : AttendsEngaged Bonnie := by
    have : InClub Bonnie := premise7a
    exact premise2 Bonnie ⟨this, hPerf⟩
  -- From premise7b and hAttend, in either case we can derive StudentAtSchool Bonnie classically:
  have hStudent : StudentAtSchool Bonnie := by
    cases premise7b with
    | inl h =>
      exact h.right
    | inr h =>
      have hnnS : ¬¬StudentAtSchool Bonnie := by
        intro hNotS
        exact h ⟨hAttend, hNotS⟩
      exact byContradiction hnnS
  -- From InClub and Student, we can show she cannot chaperone (or else contradict premise4):
  have hNoChap : ¬ChaperonesDances Bonnie := by
    intro hChap
    have hNotStudent : ¬StudentAtSchool Bonnie := premise4 Bonnie ⟨premise7a, hChap⟩
    exact hNotStudent hStudent
  -- From premise3, Bonnie is either performing often or inactive; if inactive then she chaperones (premise5), contradicting hNoChap.
  -- However, this only eliminates the 'inactive' branch and does not yield a contradiction from the assumption hPerf itself.
  -- Therefore, the negation ¬PerformsOften Bonnie does not follow from the given premises via this route.
  sorry

premises:
Not true and false is false. All employees who schedule a meeting with their customers will go to the company building today. 
Everyone who has lunch in the company building schedules meetings with their customers. 
Employees have lunch either in the company building or at home.
If an employee has lunch at home, they are working remotely from home.
All employees who are in other countries work remotely from home. 
No managers work remotely from home. 
James will appear in the company today if and only if he is a manager.
conclusion: James has lunch in the company.
true_response:
<lean>
-- Entities and predicates
axiom Person : Type
axiom James : Person

axiom Employee : Person → Prop
axiom Manager : Person → Prop
axiom LunchInCompany : Person → Prop
axiom LunchAtHome : Person → Prop
axiom SchedulesMeetingsWithCustomers : Person → Prop
axiom GoToCompanyBuildingToday : Person → Prop
axiom WorksRemotelyFromHome : Person → Prop
axiom InOtherCountries : Person → Prop
axiom AppearsInCompanyToday : Person → Prop

-- Premise: Not true and false is false. (We formalize a harmless tautology)
axiom p1 : ¬ (True ∧ False)

-- Premise: All employees who schedule a meeting with their customers will go to the company building today.
axiom p2 : ∀ x : Person, Employee x ∧ SchedulesMeetingsWithCustomers x → GoToCompanyBuildingToday x

-- Premise: Everyone who has lunch in the company building schedules meetings with their customers.
axiom p3 : ∀ x : Person, LunchInCompany x → SchedulesMeetingsWithCustomers x

-- Premise: Employees have lunch either in the company building or at home.
axiom p4 : ∀ x : Person, Employee x → (LunchInCompany x ∨ LunchAtHome x)

-- Premise: If an employee has lunch at home, they are working remotely from home.
axiom p5 : ∀ x : Person, (Employee x ∧ LunchAtHome x) → WorksRemotelyFromHome x

-- Premise: All employees who are in other countries work remotely from home.
axiom p6 : ∀ x : Person, (Employee x ∧ InOtherCountries x) → WorksRemotelyFromHome x

-- Premise: No managers work remotely from home.
axiom p7 : ∀ x : Person, Manager x → ¬ WorksRemotelyFromHome x

-- Premise: James will appear in the company today iff he is a manager.
axiom p8 : AppearsInCompanyToday James ↔ Manager James

-- Conclusion to analyze: James has lunch in the company.
theorem goal : LunchInCompany James := by
  -- From the given premises alone, the conclusion does not follow.
  -- There is no premise asserting that James is an employee, nor that he appears/goes to the company,
  -- and there is no link between appearing and going to the building. Hence we cannot derive LunchInCompany James.
  sorry
</lean>

PROOF STATUS: FAILED

false_response:
<lean>
-- Entities and predicates
axiom Person : Type
axiom Employee : Person → Prop
axiom Manager : Person → Prop
axiom James : Person
axiom AppearsToday : Person → Prop
axiom LunchCompany : Person → Prop
axiom LunchHome : Person → Prop
axiom SchedulesMeeting : Person → Prop
axiom RemoteWFH : Person → Prop
axiom InOtherCountries : Person → Prop

-- Premises
axiom tautology : ¬(True ∧ False)
axiom sched_implies_appear : ∀ e : Person, Employee e → SchedulesMeeting e → AppearsToday e
axiom lunchCompany_implies_schedule : ∀ e : Person, LunchCompany e → SchedulesMeeting e
axiom employee_lunch_either_or : ∀ e : Person, Employee e → (LunchCompany e ∨ LunchHome e)
axiom lunchHome_implies_remote : ∀ e : Person, LunchHome e → RemoteWFH e
axiom abroad_implies_remote : ∀ e : Person, InOtherCountries e → RemoteWFH e
axiom managers_not_remote : ∀ e : Person, Manager e → ¬RemoteWFH e
axiom james_appear_iff_manager : AppearsToday James ↔ Manager James
axiom james_is_employee : Employee James

-- Goal: Prove the negation of the conclusion "James has lunch in the company."
theorem not_lunch_company_James : ¬LunchCompany James := by
  intro hLunchCompany
  have hSched : SchedulesMeeting James := lunchCompany_implies_schedule James hLunchCompany
  have hAppear : AppearsToday James := sched_implies_appear James james_is_employee hSched
  have hMgr : Manager James := (james_appear_iff_manager).mp hAppear
  have hNotRemote : ¬RemoteWFH James := managers_not_remote James hMgr
  -- To derive a contradiction, we would need RemoteWFH James.
  -- From the given premises, RemoteWFH James follows from LunchHome James
  -- or James being in other countries, neither of which is derivable from the assumptions at hand.
  -- Hence we are stuck.
  sorry
</lean>

PROOF STATUS: FAILED
